contextId.information: Paul uses the word "name" as a metonym to refer to Jesus. AT: "in order to teach all nations to obey because of their faith in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: for obedience of faith among all the nations, for the sake of his name

contextId.information: The word "name" is a metonym that refers to the entirety of God, not just his name. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: name of God

contextId.information: Here "heart" is a metonym for the inner person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: of the heart

contextId.information: Here "wrath" is a metonym for God's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: his wrath

contextId.information: The word "throat" is a metonym for everything that people say that is unrighteous and disgusting. Here "open grave" is a metaphor that refers to the stench of the evil words of the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their throat is an open grave

contextId.information: Here the "glory of God" is a metonym that refers to the image of God and his nature. AT: "and have failed to be like God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: and come short of the glory of God

contextId.information: This is a metonym for the death of Jesus as a sacrifice for sins. AT: "in his death as a sacrifice for sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: in his blood

contextId.information: Here "circumcision" is a metonym that refers to Jews and "uncircumcision" is a metonym that refers to non-Jews. AT: "God will make both Jews and non-Jews right with himself through their faith in Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: he will justify the circumcision by faith, and the uncircumcision through faith

contextId.information: This is a metonym that refers to the people who are not Jews. AT: "the Gentiles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: those of the uncircumcision

contextId.information: Here "wrath" is a metonym that refers to God's punishment of those who have sinned against him. AT: "God's punishment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the wrath of God

contextId.information: This is a metonym that refers to the whole sinful person. AT: "our sinful nature" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the body of sin

contextId.information: Often Paul uses the word "flesh" as the opposite of "spirit." AT: "because you do not fully understand spiritual things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: because of the weakness of your flesh

contextId.information: Here "children of the flesh" is a metonym that refers to the physical descendants of Abraham. AT: "not all of Abraham's descendants" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the children of the flesh are not

contextId.information: Here "heart" is a metonym that represents the mind or will. AT: "For it is with the mind that a person trusts and is right before God, and it is with the mouth that a person confesses and God saves him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: For with the heart man believes for righteousness, and with the mouth he acknowledges for salvation

contextId.information: Here the word "name" is a metonym for Jesus. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "The Lord will save everyone who trusts in him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: For everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved

contextId.information: Here "the world" is a metonym for the people who live in the world. AT: "the people in the world" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: the world

contextId.information: This refers to unbelievers who live in the world. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: this world

contextId.information: Here "wrath" is a metonym for God's punishment. AT: "allow God to punish them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: give way to the wrath of God

contextId.information: Here "wrath" represents the punishment people receive when they do evil deeds. AT: "a person who punishes people as an expression of the government's anger against evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: an avenger for wrath

contextId.information: Here the "flesh" refers to the self-directed nature of people who oppose God. This is the sinful nature of human beings. AT: "do not allow your old evil heart any opportunity at all for doing wicked things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: make no provision for the flesh

contextId.information: Here to be of the "same mind" is a metonym that means to be in agreement with each other. AT: "to be in agreement with each other" or "to be united" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: to be of the same mind with each other

contextId.information: Here "the circumcision" is a metonym that refers to the Jews. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "Jesus Christ came to help the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Christ has been made a servant of the circumcision

contextId.information: Here "stomach" is a metonym that refers to physical desires. Serving there stomach represents satisfying their desires. AT: "but they only want to satisfy their own selfish desires" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] )
contextId.quote: but their own stomach
